scripts.test: if port-is-taken --silent 4000 ; then npm run _ci_seq; else npm run -s _test_1 ; fi
scripts._test_1: concurrently --kill-others --success=first --prefix none "npm run start" "wait-for 4000 && npm test"
scripts.ci:seq: concurrently --kill-others --success=first -n emul,test "npm run ci:start" "wait-for 4000 && npm run -s _ci_seq"
scripts._ci_seq: npm run test:fns:all && npm run test:rules:all
scripts.//ci:par: concurrently --kill-others --success=first -n emul,test "npm run -s ci:start" "wait-for 4000 && npm run -s _ci_par"
scripts.//_ci_par: concurrently -n test-fns,test-rules "npm run test:fns:all" "npm run test:rules:all"
scripts.start: $(docker-run-cmd) firebase emulators:start --project=demo-2 | grep -v -E "Detected demo project ID|You are not signed in to the Firebase CLI|You are not currently authenticated so some features"
scripts.ci:deploy: npm run -s _prepFunctions && npm run -s _prepDeploy && firebase deploy --only functions,firestore

engines.npm: There is no single *pressing* reason why, but the two (6 vs. 7) seem slightly incompatible. Instead of being
bitten by this, since npm 7 is now stable and released, let's require it.
NOTE: 'npm@6' does not seem to observe the 'engines.npm' - it still runs!

ci:start: DO NOT use '|' in the CI side. The combination of Alpine Linux, 'concurrently' and piping creates a problem,
where the killing of the emulators hits a wrong process id, and CI run never finishes. See TRACK.md
